Ottawa, November 23, 1933.

Sir!

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant I beg to say that in view of your report regarding Andrew McGahy, it will not be necessary to insist on his attending the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary

A. Highfield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
Sir,

Re-Eldridge McNahey,

Eldridge McNahey was returned to his home from the Shingwauk home, owing to a bad habit which he practiced on himself as well as other boys.

Since his return home he has been attending No. 2 school. The teacher Mrs. Athel George would say that this boy did not come to school. Eldridge is now 15 years old, Eldridge in the fourth form. Mrs. George had thought that if he done well she might have his entrance June next. He does not seem to be trying very hard, Mrs. George feel that the school would be better without his attendance.

Would the department think it advisable to compel his attendance at school, or allow him to discontinue?

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
St. John's Rectory
WALPOLE ISLAND

R.R. 3, Wallaceburg, Ont., Nov. 2, 193—

Mr. Highfield,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island.

Dear Mr. Highfield:

In calling at the schools on the Island I find the number of children attending school is very small. Sunday School attendance is also very low at the United Church.

I was wondering if I could get permission to hold a Sunday School class at the school from 3:00 to 4:00 in the afternoon on Sundays. The children would be able to attend the school classes after 4:00.

It seems to me to be a pity that these children should be neglected & I am willing to give instruction in Bible classes.
Ottawa, November 27, 1934.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, enclosing letter received from Rev. Mr. Hall requesting permission to give instruction on biblical lines at the Walpole Island No. 2 School.

At the present time the Department is not prepared to approve religious teaching at this school before the regular closing hour. It is noted from your letter that approximately 75% of the parents of the children attending this school are members of the United Church, and it is just possible that the United Church missionary might object to Mr. Hall conducting religious services on the Reserve.

I believe that the best course to take would be for you to arrange to have Rev. Mr. Hall and the United Church missionary meet and discuss the situation, and allow them to decide whatever action will be mutually satisfactory. In the event of it being decided to give certain religious instructions at the Walpole Island No. 2 School, it should be understood that this will only be given after the regular hour of closing, viz., 4 P.M.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Highfield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
Sir,

I beg to enclose letter from Rev. Wm. Hall Rector of the Anglican Church of Walpole Island.

This letter is self-explanatory.

For your information I might say that I estimate that 75 per cent of the people in the No. 2 school section are United Church adherents. There is no resident minister of the United Church living on the reserve just now. The minister from the Sarnia Reserve preaches here once each Sunday. It appears that they do not have any Sunday school just now. In the past they did have.

I suggested this to Rev. Hall that he try and have his Sunday school Sunday afternoon and not interfere with the day school. But he was afraid that the United Church people might feel that he was trying to interfere with their work. It is Mr. Hall's intention to have these lessons in the school room.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
St. John's Rectory

R.R. 3, Wallaceburg, Ont.

Ottawa, March 4, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, informing the Department that, owing to the death of her father, Mrs. George closed the No. 2 School, Walpole Island, for a period of four days; also that Mrs. James Daley, teacher of the junior room at the No. 1 School, would not be able to teach for a period of over a week owing to illness.

When it is necessary for a teacher to be absent for a few days on account of illness or for family reasons, school will have to remain closed. Should it be necessary for a teacher to be absent for any lengthy period, the matter should immediately be reported to the Department, stating the probable length of such absence. When, if considered necessary, authority will be given to obtaining the services of a substitute. When a teacher is absent for a period of over five days on account of illness, a doctor's certificate should be forwarded, in order that salary can be paid.

As Mrs. Daley will, no doubt, be able to resume duties at an early date, it will not be necessary to obtain a substitute. If Mr. Daley cannot arrange to take a number of the junior pupils into his room, the junior room will have to remain closed until Mrs. Daley is able to resume duties.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Highfield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
Sir,

Re-Schools.

For your information I would beg to say that owing to the death of Mrs. Ethel George father there was no school at No.2 school from Tuesday Feb.24 to Monday Feb.27 being closed 4 days the 21,22,23,24.

Mrs. James only teacher in the junior room at No.2 school, owing to illness was not able to teach Thursday or Friday the 23 and 24. This morning Dr. Rowland said it would be necessary for Mrs. Daley to remain in bed another two day and that she should not teach again this week. What are the regulations on the reserves in respect to day allowed teacher under pay for time lost for illness. There are qualified teacher available here but I understand that he has been unable of these teacher to take charge of Mrs. Daley room for a week. Mrs. Daley did not care to do so and become responsible for there pay, and I felt that the Department would not care to pay two teacher for the same room.

What would be the Department wish if Mrs. Daley sickness should be extended for a longer time or in the future if a similar case should arise.

Section 165 sub-section(4) of the provincial school act said in part:- Every teacher shall be entitled to his salary notwithstanding his absence from duty on account of sickness for a period not exceeding four weeks in any one year of his employment if the sickness is certified to by a Physician.

The Secretary,
Your obedient servant,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Ont.
Ottawa, February 23, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Mrs. George, teacher in the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School, regarding a pupil, George Isaac, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Isaac. The Department has noted the trouble this boy has occasioned and the difficulty the teacher has had with him and his father.

It is considered that action should be taken to prevent Allan Isaac interfering with the classroom work and discipline of the school. You may, therefore, in conjunction with the R.C.W.P., lay a charge against Allan Isaac, provided that, after due warning, he does not cease his interference with the work of the school and annoying the teacher. He should be made to understand that his son is to be amenable to the discipline of the school and is to conduct himself properly in the classroom. It is necessary that Mrs. George be protected in her duties as teacher and that all pupils comply with the discipline of the classroom.

The Department does not consider it advisable to have the boy placed in a reform school. We regret that at the present time there is no vacancy in any of our residential schools in which he could be placed.

Your obedient servant,

A. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Highfield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
Ottawa, December 10, 1930.

Sir:

The Department has received a further communication from Allan Isaac, relative to the complaints made by him regarding the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School. He states that she continues to show discrimination against his children, and that she has reported them as being absent from school when they were in attendance. He also states that the teacher sends his children home at three o'clock, while she keeps the other children in school until the regular closing period.

I have to request that you will arrange at your earliest convenience to interview both Allan Isaac and the teacher with a view to straightening out any difficulty there may be between them. This man should understand that it is expected that children will attend school regularly and comply in all respects with the regular discipline. You should also inform the teacher that it is expected she will see that no discrimination is exercised by her against any of the pupils who attend. The Department desires that the frequent complaints of Allan Isaac will cease, and you should use every endeavour to smooth out any difficulties there may be between the teacher and himself.

Please inform the Department of the result of any action taken by you in the matter; also inform Allan Isaac that his communication has been received by the Department and that you have been instructed to deal with the matter of the complaints made by him.

Your obedient servant,

A. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

A. Highfield, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
40° Wapole Island
Dec. 14th 1930

To A.J. McKenzie Esq.,
Rec. Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter Oct. 20th No. 40-2-1 I beg to say that the Indian Agent did not inquire into all complaints as I asked some of the Complainants who informed me that he has not inquired of them.

He told the teacher of the Complaints and while she tried to make improvements still showed discrimination against my children and is still doing so.

She also thinks some nasty remarks about us before the children, who invariably tell us about said remarks.

Walter Wright showed me a report of the attendance of the children showing that my boy R. George Isaac attended only 5 days during the month of November and thirty only in December. Now as we live 10 miles from the road (about one hundred steps) I am all that is going on, and also I have sent his children to school every day, so this is some mistake or misunderstanding, showing my children do not attend school.
She does send my children home at 3 o'clock every day while she keeps the other children till 4 o'clock.

If there is no improvement in the treatment of my children I am inclined to keep them at home till there is a change & teacher.

And I am not the only parent who's children are discriminated against and they have to attend this school, so we as parents of the said children feel it a necessity of a change of teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Allan Isaac
Laura Isaac.
shipman (whom I consider quite a reliable Indian) at that when Mr. Sampson first began spending evenings at the school and at various times since, he has been very kind to pay particular attention owing to various matters that would persist in coming up, that he has never appeared to be in any way interested in the welfare of the pupils.

I have always found Mr. Sampson living around the school grounds and attending to his own business. He has never been seen doing anything that might be considered suspicious or dangerous.

On the contrary, Mr. Sampson has always been very attentive to the needs of the pupils and has always been willing to assist them in any way possible.

I am quite provoked at the thought of Mr. Sampson being involved in any such matter. It is not likely that he would be able to do anything to help the pupils. No action was taken against Mr. Sampson because there was no evidence of ill will.

Sincerely,

Wolfe Island
Oct. 2nd 1930

We, the undersigned do herein make the following Complaints against Miss Ethel George, the school teacher of No. 2 School of Wolfe Island.

1st The children are always fighting, and although reported, the teacher does not punish them.

2nd When the bell rings in calling the children to school, there is no system consequently there is often a jam at the doors causing sometimes injuries to the children.

3rd Although being a married woman having a husband living, there is a man at least once a day every night residence at the school, almost for 4 years.

In view of the circumstances surrounding the ward as a school, there is no discipline at the school, and we deem it necessary that there should be a change of teacher.

Signed,

Allan Isaac
Ottawa, October 20, 1930.

Sir:

The Department has received the enclosed petition regarding the teacher of the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School. I have to request that you will make enquiry regarding this matter and furnish the Department with a report. When forwarding your report, please return the enclosed communication.

Ottawa, December 7th, 1929.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Walpole Isl'd. Agency.

No. 8 school is in charge of Mrs. Edith E. George who has only a commercial certificate but has twenty-five years' teaching experience. There are thirty-eight pupils on the roll. Attendance is reported as very good and progress fair. Besides the regular curriculum the pupils are taught knitting, sewing, mending, dressmaking and manual training. The classroom was clean and well ventilated. The teacher's residence attached was very tidy and well kept and reflects great credit upon Mrs. George.

Thos. McCookin.
Inspector.
E. X.

July 21st, 1955.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th instant applying for the position as teacher of the Walpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School in the event of a vacancy occurring and stating the qualifications which you possess.

In reply I beg to say that insofar as we are aware it is the intention of Mrs. George, the present teacher, to resume duties when this school reopens after the present summer holidays. Your application is, however, being placed on file and will receive consideration should a vacancy occur.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

V. Palmer MacDougall, Esq.,
Walpole Island, Ont.
Walpole Island, Ont.
July 15th, 1926

Russell T. Harris
Sup't Indian Education
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

In the event of a vacancy occurring in No. 2 Indian School, Walpole Island, Ont. I beg to make application for the position as teacher.

I hold the following qualifications:

II. ma Class Certificate
Complete Junior Matriculation
Scoutmaster's Certificate

Should my application be accepted, I have permission from the Rev. Bishop of Huron, Bishop's, London, Ont., to read for the church while teaching.

Am employed as book keeper accountant, but owing to the fact that my little boy has been injured in an automobile accident and must have perfect quietness I am anxious of securing a position in an Indian day school.
My wife, who is a professional artist, would be willing to take charge of the musical education in the school.

Should my application be accepted, I shall do all in my power to make a success of the work.

Sincerely,

W. Fraser MacDougall.
Ottawa, June 12th, 1925.

Sir:

In further reference to the complaint which was made by yourself and Andrew Isaac regarding the conduct of Mrs. Ethel George, teacher of the No. 2 School on Walpole Island Reserve, I have now to inform you that, after enquiry, it was found that there is no foundation for the complaint made by you and Andrew Isaac. The parties whom you report as visiting the teacher at night are her relatives. The neighbors who have been interviewed in the matter state that there is nothing wrong in these visits.

I need not point out to you the seriousness of making unfounded reports, or the situation in which you place yourselves if action were to be taken by the teacher or others in having you prove the charges. The Department does not desire to have any further unfounded charges, and is taking no action to have a change made in the teacher at this school for the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Mr. Joseph Sampson,
Walpole Island,
Ont.
Ottawa, June 4th, 1925.

Sir:

A complaint has reached the Department regarding the teacher of the No. 2 school on the Walpole Island Reserve. The following is an extract from the letter received:

"Teacher has had men often playing cards late in the night at her apartments in the school building. Men have been seen to go see her in the school occasionally. Teacher keeping some of her relatives or men folks till 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning is certainly showing a bad example. She has a husband living.

May we beg to ask that the teacher be dispensed with. Get some one who will take hold and set an example to others for the sake of our school. New teacher to come in by September 1st.

Please enquire into the matters complained of and inform the Department whether you would recommend that a change be made in the teacher at this school for the next school year. Your early reply is desired."

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.
Ottawa, June 4th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, making certain complaints regarding the teacher of the No. 8 school on the Walpole Island Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that enquiry will be made into these complaints.

Dear Mr. Jarvis,

A petition was signed by parents of the school children against Mr. Watts former teacher of No. 2 Pitt School and recommended by the joint council of both Bands (regular monthly meeting) dated August 21st, 1923. Mr. Watts was then transferred to Little Point where he was given charge of school. His husband belongs in the Band. We have heard from Mr. Roy Abraham, Shatton, representative of the Department and the Indian Agent Mr. Fred Sarris, made the change of teachers and nothing said of the petition. Thirdly let me know if the petition has reached the Department.

Yours respectfully,
Joseph Dunstan
Route 3
Waipole Island
May 26th, 1925

Mrs. Finnie,
Sup't School Board,

Sir:

I have written Mrs. Ethel Guigues of No. 2 Post Office, with you to direct your attention.

She has been seen often playing cards late in the night at her residence in the school building.

Men had been seen going to her during the day occasionally.

I have heard from some one not the district officer, that she was late in the morning in returning, showing a bad example she has as a husband living.

May we beg to ask that the teacher be dismissed with immediate effect who will take hold and set an example to others for the sake of our schools.

New teacher's name is by September 1st.

Respectfully yours,

Joseph Campbell (Board)

Ottawa, May 30, 1926.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Mrs. Harriette Macpherson, formerly teacher teacher at the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day School, wishes to secure a position in one of the Indian schools at Walpole Island for the ensuing academic year. As you are aware, there will be only vacancy in the Walpole Island schools, so Mrs. Wall is living up duty at the end of June.

The Department wishes to give Mrs. Macpherson's application favourable consideration. She is willing to take either room in No. 1 School or the No. 2 School. If she takes the junior room at Walpole Island No. 1, she will be content to have one of the upstairs rooms only as her share of the residence, so she would arrange to rent a cottage in the vicinity.

The Department will agree to any arrangement which is considered in the best interests of the Indian children of the Island. If Mrs. Savage wishes to transfer to the junior room at Walpole Island No. 1 at the same salary she is now receiving, this action can be taken. If Mrs. Savage wishes to transfer to the No. 2 School because of the better residence facilities, such action would be approved.

Please give this question your careful and earliest consideration and discuss the matter with Mr. Indian Agent and as well as with both Mrs. Savage and Mrs. George. A copy of this letter is being directed to Mr. Indian Agent, so that he will be prepared to make an intelligent recommendation when you get in touch with him.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Maclean,
Acting Deputy Secretary.

P. H. Maclean, M.P.,
Agricultural Representative,
R.R. 74,
Chatham, Ont.
May 30, 1924.

MEMO FOR FILE:

Mrs. H. Macpherson, who was formerly at the No. 1 School, wishes to return to Walpole Island for the coming academic year. She is willing to take either room in the No. 1 School or the No. 2 School. She is willing to accept $700 in the event that she takes the junior room and has no general responsibilities and will be content, in this event, to have one of the upstairs rooms only as her share of the residence.

It is understood that, if she takes the responsibility for No. 1 School or the No. 2 School, a salary of $800 would be offered.

Ottawa, Nov. 28th, 1923.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that it has been decided to approve of the exchange of teachers at the Walpole Island No. 2 and Kettle Point Indian Day Schools. This exchange is to date from the last of January, next. Mr. Harold D. Watts, the present teacher at the No. 2 school, is to take charge of the Kettle Point School, and Mrs. A. George, the present teacher at Kettle Point, is to take charge of the No. 2 school at Walpole Island. The salary allowed both these teachers will be at the same rate as they are at present receiving, viz: $650 per annum to Mrs. George, and $650 per annum to Mr. Watts. The salary, in both cases, will be supplemented by the bonus provided by law.

I shall be pleased if you will inform both the above named teachers accordingly, and arrange for them to exchange duties on the above mentioned date.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Thos. Paul, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Barnes, Ont.
Ottawa, Nov. 26th, 1923,

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th instant, in which you recommend the exchange of teachers between the Walpole Island No. 2 and Kettle Point Indian Day Schools.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve, to date from January 1st next, of the transfer of Mr. Harold D. Watts, the present teacher of the No. 2 school, to the Kettle Point School, and of Mrs. Angus George fr a Kettle Point to take charge of the Walpole Island No. 2 school. The salary allowed will be at the same rate as they are now receiving, viz: $650 per annum to Mrs. George and $600 per annum to Mr. Watts. The salary, in both cases, will be supplemented by the bonus provided by law.

We are informing Mr. Agent Paul of approval having been granted for the exchange of teachers at the two above named schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. H. Abraham, Esq.,
Agricultural Representative,
Chatham, Ont.
In reference to the question of changing teachers at Walpole Island No. 2 school, I beg to say that Mr. George at the Kettle Point school is very anxious to get a school somewhere not so far from Sarnia, and would like very much to go to the No. 2 school Walpole Island. Mr. Watts the present teacher at No. 2 Walpole Island would be agreeable to make the change. I beg to recommend that Mr. George be employed at No. 2 school Walpole Island and that Mr. Watts be removed to Kettle Point at the same wages he is receiving now.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

J.D. McLean,
The Secretary,
Dept. of Ind. Aff.,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 17, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing a petition signed by certain parents and guardians of children attending the Walpole Island No. 1 Indian Day school. A copy of this petition also was received direct from the Band. I have also noted the minute of the Walpole Island Council, dated the 6th instant.

I have to inform you that the Department is desirous of securing a better qualified incumbent for the position of teacher in this school than the present teacher. You will please advise Mr. Watt that his services will not be required after the end of the calendar year. By this time the new building will be ready for occupation and the Department, in conjunction with your office, will arrange for a qualified teacher. You may inform the members of the Council and the petitioners of this decision.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Theo. Paul, Esq.,

July 81-1923

We have complained to the Department of Education about the condition of the school at Wolfville Indian Reserve. We request that the Department make a change of teacher to commence next Sept. 1923.

We do hereby submit the following complaints against Mr. Watts (teacher) of No. 12 School:

1. Teacher lets the children leave school earlier than 4 o'clock.
2. Teacher lets the children have recess longer than usual.
3. Children look out during school through the windows toward who is driving along the road.
4. Children are not making any progress in school.
5. Parents or others visiting the school found that the pupils are noisy, or would get into self-talking to friends.
6. When pupils enter, all stand in groups all read the same time, others would be talking to each other.
7. A child was taught how and when in the Primer Reader. In the First Reader or Christian Reader when examined by the Parent the child did not know the first half of the Primer figures up to 20.

8. Teacher uses tobacco during School.

9. Geography class. A whole school is taught together classes should not be kept back for the sake of the Primary class.

Signed

Mary Anne & William
Isaac Lampton
William Isaac
Laura Isaac
George Isaac
Jonathan Shipman
Joseph Shipman
Samuel Shipman
Elijah Shipman

Yours Truly,
Joseph Hamilton

Jarnia, Ontario.

Aug. 8th, 1923.

Sir,

Enclosed find Petition, signed by a number of Parents, and Guardians of Children attending the H.O.M. school, Walpole Island, which speaks for itself.

I might say, that I have visited Mr. Hatt's school quite often when on my visits to Walpole Island, and any time I visited his school, the order was good, and Mr. Hatt appeared to be very much interested in his work.

In cases of this kind, I think the Public School Inspector's report should govern.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

J.B. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir:

We, the undersigned, Parents & Guardians
of children attending the Potowatamie School
No. 2, Walpole Island, Indian Reserve, do
request that the Department make a change
of the teacher, to commence next Sept., 1923.
We do hereby submit the following
complaints against Mr. Watts, teacher of No.
2 School.

1. Teacher either late or leaves the children out
earlier than 4 o'clock.
2. Teacher lets the children have recess longer
than 1 hour or more.
3. Children look out during school through
the windows to see who is driving along the
road.
4. Children are not making any progress
in school.
5. Parents & others visiting the School found the
children are noisy & would go to other seat
talking to a friend.
6. When pupils read, all stand in groups, all read

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Abraham, while in the Department last week, recommended that the salary of Harold D. Watts, teacher of the No. 2 School, Walpole Island Reserve, be increased by $50.00, which would give him the same rate of salary as is paid the teacher of the No. 1 School. He is at present receiving a salary of $600.00 and the bonus, while the teacher of the No. 1 School receives $650.00 salary and bonus. There is an enrolment of 49 pupils at the No. 2 School and 53 at the No. 1 School.

Mr. Watts was trained in England and had thirteen years teaching experience there, and has had five years experience in Canada. The Public School Inspector states that "the success he met with is reasonably good. The pupils can all speak English. They are making fairly good progress. I believe the work that is being done in agriculture has considerable value. Hygiene and physical culture are receiving proper attention."

Mrs. McDonald, teacher of the No. 1 School, has only a Third Class certificate but has had twenty-one years experience.

I would recommend that Mr. Watts' salary be increased by $50.00, which would allow him the same salary as is paid Mrs. McDonald and would place them on an equal footing for the same amount of work.

Sir,

Your letter of Jan 23rd, no. 152943-1 received. I could not reply sooner as I wished to see the agent Mr. McMillan before I wrote. I went down to see him last Sunday but he was not at home; then followed a big thaw and the roads were a mass of slush and mud. The round trip from the school house to the agent's residence at the front and back to my place is nearly six miles so could not go down till last evening.

Now I wish to say here that if my remarks are a little vigorous it is without prejudice toward the Indian Department as I appreciate the courteous consideration you have given me during the past seven years.

More respectfully, but emphatically, I say to say that any report you may have that states that my health is not of the best is an absolute falsehood. My age I can't deny and don't
I have never had better health in my life than I have at present and I have always had good health. I could show you the amount of work I have done during the past autumn in gathering a small load in the woods and carrying it in bundles about a quarter of a mile to my house for my winter's supply of fuel.

In regard to school work I have received compliments indirectly from those most interested, on my efforts to teach the children the English language which has not been done by previous teachers, at least not for a few years past. I don't know how many are in the plot against me but I do know the instigator of the whole thing, "and thereby hangs a tale." I am the victim of a vile plot. I could tell the whole story but I am not
pleading to stay here only as I shall state shortly on. I don't mind the dismissal so much as I do the manner in which it has been brought about by an "enemy in the camp."

Now I would respectfully ask for one last favor from the Department: I live alone in a rented log house about 15 miles from the schoolhouse. It is difficult to get supplies as it is about seven (or six) miles to Wallaceburg and I have to drive a rig when I go there. It is difficult to get a conveyance and when one does so the Indians consider a white man as their lawful prey so far as money is concerned. Because of these difficulties I have laid in my winter's stock of eatables such as potatoes, bacon, apples (that grow on the place), sugar, tea, coffee, flour, etc. I have also a big pile of wood referred to above.
which is admirable but which serves me well as it is dry and small for my little store.

Now because of these facts I esteem it a great favor if you could, or rather would, let me stay on till the summer holidays when I shall bid the schoolhouse farewell forever.

In the spring this place is a sea of mud. Then there are some things I must dispose of—a stone table, bedstead and mattress, tools, nails etc.

Another reason I have is, I may stay here awhile after the school closes, and have some of my family come up from Toronto to stay awhile.

Your obedient servant,

Geo. Lark

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the petition sent in by some of the Valpole Island Indians asking for the appointment of a qualified teacher to replace Mr. Joseph Sampson I beg to say that Mr. Agent McCallum was asked to report fully on this petition and Mr. Sampson's letter in regard thereto. Mr. McCallum has replied stating that he has known for sometime that a change of teachers in the No. 2 School would be advantageous. He has, however, failed to deal with the points made by Mr. Sampson in his letter, in which he claims that Chomee, who is the instigator of this petition, is actuated by spite and that some of the signers of the petition have no children of school age, only four out of the eight having children attending the school.

Mr. Sampson has been teaching this school for the past fourteen years. The Department is aware that he has no special qualifications and possibly a change would be advantageous. Mr. Conn, Public School Inspector, who visited...
visited this school on the 1st of October, last, in his report in speaking of Sampson states "success only fair, but I think his work is improving and the pupils are making somewhat better progress in their studies".

It would be a difficult matter to obtain a qualified, white teacher for this school, as in the No. 1 School they have had seven teachers in the last four years and the present teacher has sent in her resignation. As Sampson has been so long in the employ of the Department I do not think it would be just to him to dismiss him summarily. Mr. McCollum will have to take steps to secure a qualified teacher for the No. 1 School and I think before doing anything with the No. 2 School we might wait to see what success he has. At any rate I would not advocate dispensing with Mr. Sampson's services till the end of the school year.

Dear Sir:

We have completed the erection of the No. 1 school at Walpole Island, and we will be in a position now to proceed with No. 2 School.

No. 2 school has a capacity at the present time for 16 pupils. There are 85 pupils of school age at the present time who should attend this school. 30 seats are crowded into this small school, and sometimes the teacher has to put them three in a seat. This building is old and very much out of date, and I would recommend that a new school be built.

The material for this building could be obtained from the public bush and made into lumber at the Indian saw mill which is only a few hundred yards from the proposed school. I would suggest that a school with a teacher's residence combined be built. The present teacher, Mr. D. White lives in an old log shack about a mile and a half from the school. We have a certain amount of material left from the erection of the No. 1 School and this could be utilized in connection with the construction of the new school.

The only time material can be got out of the woods is during the winter, and if it is your intention to proceed with the building next year, the material should be taken out this winter. The cost of erecting this building should be, approximately, between three and four thousand dollars.

Memorandum

Honourable Charles Stewart:

Funds to the amount of $3,500 have been provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the present fiscal year to erect a dormitory school and teacher's living quarters at the No. 1 school on the Walpole Island Indian Reserve, Lambton County. During the past winter the Indians themselves have cut the lumber from their supply on the reserve and have drawn it to a mill belonging to one of the band, where it will be sawn into the required sizes.

The present school building is very old, beyond repair, and is unsuitable for school purposes. It is proposed to erect this new building by Indian labour, under the supervision of a competent foreman. This was the arrangement that was carried out in the erection of a combined 2-roomed school and teacher's residence at the No. 1 school. All arrangements for carrying out the building operations and the cutting and sawing of the lumber will be under the direct oversight of our agricultural representative, Mr. R. H. Abraham, who will arrange for the payment of the labour employed, sawing and hauling the timber, etc. It is intended to proceed with the work of erecting the building as soon as possible, and Mr. Abraham has requested that advances be sent him from time to time to pay for the labour, etc.

It is considered that we can erect this building by utilizing Indian labour under a competent foreman, at least cost than if we called for public tenders. The estimated cost will be $3,500.00, and I would request your approval for having the work done, as stated above, and for the expenditure required.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

Relative to conversation with you while in the Department yesterday regarding matters in connection with the Maliseet Island No. 2 Indian Day School, I beg to inform you that you may arrange to have a suitable fence erected around the school grounds, and you may also arrange to have a walk built from the front of the school building to the road. You should also arrange to have the woodshed moved from its present position to a suitable site.

As the old school building will not be further required, you should arrange to sell the same to the person making the highest offer. The money received for this old building should be forwarded to the Department for credit to the funds of the Potawatomi Band.

No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred in the fencing, building of the walk and moving of the woodshed. In the purchase of any material required, competitive prices should, if possible, be obtained. Proper time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept by the labor employed. Properly verified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred when the work has been completed. The above authorized work should receive your early attention.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Valpole Island No. 2 Indian Day School, states that the desks in the classrooms are badly arranged. He suggests that desks of the same size be placed in the same row, running from front to rear. Please consult the teacher regarding this matter, and, if possible, have a re-arrangement made in the present position of the desks, in order to comply with the Inspector's recommendation.

I shall be pleased to hear later as to what steps you have taken to carry out this suggestion.

Sir:

I beg to report on the condition of the well and pump at No. 2 School. The threads on the pipe are gone and we cannot hold the pipe to the pump head only by letting it rest on the bottom and the pipe is so badly twisted that it will not hold the new pipe. I beg to enclose the quarterly report from No. 1 and No. 2 Walpole Island Indian day school quarter ending March 31, 1935.

In reference to the requisition from Ethel M., teacher of No. 2 school I might say that no doubt the floor in the garage would be a great convenience as two rooms do not suit at all times of year. If flooring the whole garage was too much expense there could be two 10 or 12 inch plank placed for the wheels two run on this would keep the tire of the ground and out of the mud and would be serviceable for several years.

I will have to make another report on this. I had arranged to have the toilets cleaned (this has not been done as yet) but at that time I discovered that the cement cistern basin had cavied in in the floor quite sure they had not, it may be possible that they have cavied in since the frost has come out of the ground. In the spring they are still very desirable to have the water seep in from the rain and till this water gets away some and the ground dry up it would be more expensive to have them cleaned. Both toilets are in the one building but there is a room between that was original used for the teacher toilet. If at any time the Department was building new toilets it would probably be better to build the boys and girls separate I am of the opinion that this toilet is still financial conditions improve.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Archie Macphail,
Indian agent,

Sir:

I beg to enclose requisition from Mrs. E. George, teacher at No. 2 School, asking that a heater be supplied for the residence.

Walpole Island Ont. May 15th 1937.

Sir,

Enclosed find letter from Mrs. Ethel H. George teacher No.2 school. In reference to flag pole I would refer the Department to official letter dated Oct. 15th 1936 file 40-2-5 they have no flag pole here and think they should have one at each school. It could be either a wooden pole or iron pipe. A few years ago we erected an iron pipe at No.1 school, this was set in cement. A high step ladder is needed at this school, for cleaning stove pipes and other work on the wall or ceiling; it should be a 7 or 8 foot step ladder. The stove pipe in this class room go the whole length of the room, every time the pipe are taken apart or put together we have to erect a platform of some kind.

Mrs. George paid a truck to move a few load of rock from the Anglican church basement to the school last winter and intended to start a rock garden at the school herself with the help of the children, she found securing the dirt to large an undertaking for herself and the children. I do not consider it would take as much dirt as she is asking for. If the Department can see their way clear to approve this, I would recommend that the necessary dirt be secured and a few plants or flowers be purchased to start a rock garden.

In reference to the back steps at residence and screen for porch has not come to my attention while at the school, therefor I can not report fully on these at the present time.

Since the highwater none of the surface wells are very good, during the present week we raised the pump at No.1 school one foot, which seemed to help considerably. Mr. Daley informs me the water is much better now. I will have the one at the back school the first of the week. This is only temporary measure, but there is so much water in the ground now that it is practically impossible to pump them dry by hand.
I would refer the Department to there letter of October 15th 1936 file 40-1-1 in reference to driving steel points for a water supply at both schools; I did not get this work done last year, so attempt was made at No.1 school. At No.2 school there was start made, it turned very cold and not completed, and the men doing the work were not experienced in this line of work. I think we are quite certain of securing water with a steel point at No.1 school, with fair prospect at No.2 school. I was talking to a man recently who has put down quite a number of well of this kind, he advises against doing this work now while the ground is so full of water, as one would secure water most any place, but would not be successful when it became drier.

If the approval that the Department gave last year remain good for the present fiscal year I will try this plan later on. At No.2 school there will have to be a new well of some kind or the bricks curbing in the old well removed as the brick are falling in, it is quite evident that if the bricks wall in removed it may cave in. It might be possible to drive a point in the bottom of this old well and fill with several feet of gravel. The gravel would prevent the wall from falling in and help purify the water.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian affairs,
Ottawa Ont.
Ottawa, May 19, 1937.

EX'D.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, you may arrange for the erection of a flag-pole at the Walpole Island #2 Indian Day School. The cost should be kept as low as possible.

You may, also, purchase a step-ladder and arrange for the drawing of the earth for the garden. A few seeds may also be secured and, if you consider that a new platform and steps at the back door are necessary, you may have this work done. The front porch may also be repaired. The cost of all these improvements should be kept as low as possible.

It is noted that you were not able to do any work last fall in regard to the walls at both schools. The authority given in official letter of October 16th, 1936, (file 40-1-8) is renewed.

Yours truly,

I can see any advantage of changing the bridge. Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the serving of a midday lunch at the Valpole Island No. 1 and Valpole Island No. 2 Schools.

With reference to the first paragraph of your letter, I would point out that you have not yet received any authority for expenditure for midday lunch purposes. It is true that you were given authority in the year 1939 but that only covered the academic year 1939-40. Instructions have repeatedly been issued to all Indian Agents that new authority must be obtained in every fiscal year.

If you consider the serving of a midday lunch necessary at these two schools, the Department has no objection to allowing the same monthly amount as previously; namely, $15.00 a month for a period of four months at the No. 1 School and $8.00 a month for a period of four months at the No. 2 School.

We are not prepared to approve the resolution of the Council with reference to expending an additional $10.00 a month from band funds. The Department does not see any necessity for this extra expenditure.

Yours truly,

Mr. Jas. H. Daley,
Indian Agent,
Valpole Island, Ont.

Dear Sir:

This Resolution was past in spite of the fact it is identical to a former Resolution passed in a Council Meeting held Nov. 3, 1931, Resolution 7 which was not approved by your Department. The Council feel that the health of the school children would be greatly improved by them getting a small quantity of bread each day at noon. They feel that this vote of $4 per month and the former vote of $10 per month is a very small item when it is for the health of their children. They asked me to explain to you that they are not passing this resolution in a spirit of rebellion but are asking you to kindly reconsider Resolution 7 on November 3, 1941, Council and to deal favorably with this.

I understand that the other grant comes from Government appropriation funds. This, of course, would be from Band funds. I regret that I had authorized the other expenditure for noon lunches without getting this authority this year in writing from your department. I understood from the teachers that at the last teacher's convention held at Moreviantown that this was more or less discussed and verbally consented by Mr. Phelan. I do not recall having heard him make the statement myself.

Yours obediently,

James W. Daley
Indian Agent

"The school building and surroundings need attention badly. The outside of the building is bad & paint in spots should be attended to this summer. The interior needs redecorating although it might be postponed another year. The boys' toilet should be repaired and toilet paper and lime placed in both toilet buildings. As well, the caretaker should be instructed to scrub the toilets regularly. This is not the teacher's job.

It is noted that there is no fire protection for the building. A good fire extinguisher should be provided as well as a ladder which would reach the roof.

The blackboards are so dirty the chalk will scarcely make a mark. If they were given a coat of the proper preparation for hypoplate board this condition could be overcome. Sometimes it would be wise to start and replace the present board with new ones changing one or two panels a year.

The roof has still not been checked nor the drinking water tested."

Dear Sir,

My attention has been drawn to the very poor attendance at the West Bay school, and to a lack of harmony between the Teacher and the Indians.

Mr. Bennett, the Separate School Inspector, speaks very highly of the work which Miss Fox is endeavouring to perform among these Indians, but it would appear that some of them are opposed to her, and are not sending their children to school.

The Indians cannot hope for any progress in their children if they do not send them regularly to school, and it might be well to consider the appointment of a truant officer.

I am writing this letter to ask you to take a personal interest in the matter, and, on the next occasion on which you visit West Bay, to discuss the question of education with the Council, and at the same time you may inform them that if the children are not sent regularly to school, the Department will have to consider enforcing the amendment to the Indian Act, passed at the last session, whereby we are empowered to place children who are not being sent to a day school in the residential schools, without the consent of their parents.

I shall be glad to hear from you, after you have had an opportunity of interviewing the Indians.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of last instant, I beg to say that owing to the absence of half of the members of Council of the West Bay band I was unable to get them together for consultation re the school matter; and on 29th instant at a meeting of the whole band I took up the matter and found a very small percentage of them that were opposed to the present teacher, and for reasons that had nothing to do with school matters.

They are universally opposed to so much time being spent in teaching catechism and religion in the school, but I told them that it was a church school and it would be the same if they were sent to Spanish Industrial school and they finally all agreed to send their children to the day school there.

Dear Sir,

I regret to announce to the Department that I have not recovered my health and will not be able to resume my position as teacher of West Bay School next September.

I deeply appreciate the kindness of the Department in granting me leave of absence with the permission to allow a substitute to replace me during the past year so that I might not lose the possibility of sharing in the superannuation benefit, should it be granted. I do not wish to forget this privilege of sharing in the superannuation benefit, but as I am anxious to recover my health in order to resume my work I intend to leave Canada for a change of climate and will be away for some months.

I would like to ask the Department if they could arrange with the local clergyman, Rev. E. Papineau, of West Bay, to secure a teacher and relieve me of the responsibility of securing a substitute and ask the Department to arrange about paying salary to the teacher.

I will be most grateful if the Department will grant me a leave of absence until I return to Canada. If my health is sufficiently restored I may apply for a position in some other Indian School.

Madam:

I have your telegram of today's date, accepting the position as teacher of the West Bay Indian Day School, Manitoulin Island. The Department will approve of your appointment, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

There should be an adequate supply of all other furnishings in the residence.

I must confess myself a little puzzled in regard to this school. It is very distinctly the poorest visited by me in the whole Manitoulin district, but whether the fault is on the part of the teacher or to be laid to the irregularity of attendance, is what I cannot determine.

With reference to official letter 12-4-1 June 15th last with extracts from Superintendent School Inspector's report.

In my opinion the attendance at this school has been very good during the last school year when you take into consideration the poor times among the Indians at West Bay where no timber was taken out last winter and the Indians have been obliged to make it possible for them for the Indians to find all their children also taking into account the fact that many of the children attending this school have nearly three miles to go which is a long distance at any time and more especially in the winter months.

The present constable and truant officer attend his duties very faithfully and efficiently and I believe he will be able to continue this work successfully.

To help the attendance I do not know of anything unless it would be to give three very good prizes for first, second and third in regular attendance for the school year.

In regard to the teacher Miss Smith, I may say that I have had no complaints from the Indians and I think that she is quite capable of doing her work well, and would recommend that she be reengaged.

I may say that the scholars at West Bay do not have the same opportunity of mixing with white people and talking English as children on some of the other reserves and for this reason they may when any stranger comes among them, with the exception of Papineau who they knew quite well they were altogether different than with Father Porchon who they have not yet really got acquainted with.

In my quarterly report for the period ending June 30th, I recommended a change of teacher for the Village School at West Bay.

As Mr. Byrne appears to be of rather excitable or hysterical temperament, I hesitated to approach him on the matter of resignation. In fact, I rather expected him to resign anyway, since he appeared to be rather dissatisfied with the salary etc., however, he has not given any resignation to this office, and I wish to emphasize the desirability and necessity for a change of teacher at this school.

I understand Mrs. Jean Lowe, a young widow woman of Killarney is available if she has not already secured a school elsewhere. This young woman is highly recommended by Inspector Greening, and unless the Department have some one else in view for West Bay, I would recommend an effort be made to engage her immediately.

Since the close of school, Chief Wm. McGregor has requested a change of teacher at Birch Island School on the grounds, the children are not making satisfactory progress.

I wish to refer to previous correspondence regarding the school situation at West Bay Reserve.

An official of the Department was to have come the latter part of March to investigate but has never arrived.

As previously stated, the farm house being rented from Joe P. Debassige is altogether inadequate for that section of the reserve, there being thirty-seven pupils enrolled with about fifty at the Village School and prospects for an increased attendance next term.

Mrs. Isabel Gingras, teacher at No. 2 School is desirous of teaching here another term and it would appear a new school will not be available by September 1st. Mr. Debassige would like to have his house next winter but we must open school in the house again in December. I would suggest we continue the rental throughout July and August to avoid moving or storing the school supplies.

Mrs. Gingras has had great difficulty in keeping down vermin in the house and if we have to begin another term in this building, we do not wish it to be occupied by anyone else during vacation. I will therefore continue to submit the usual vouchers for rental during July and August.
At the Village School, Miss DesCoteaux suggested that part of the living quarters should be converted into a classroom and engage two teachers.

This would necessitate considerable alterations and although it might serve as an emergency, would not be very satisfactory.

It would appear that accommodation should be provided at West Bay Reserve for a maximum of one hundred pupils and one graded school may be the solution; however, something should be done immediately to relieve the situation.

I acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 19-13-1 (E.1) dated March 9, 1948 with reference to Birch Island and West Bay Bay Schools. I have discussed with Miss Morris the matter of taking the senior room at West Bay Village School when she is able to resume work after her operation and although Miss Morris would not definitely commit herself, I can see that she would prefer not to go to West Bay.

is very fine, but I fear we will not send any children to school. I had discussed with a great many of the settlers the matter of having one larger school in the Village and practically all appeared to be greatly in favour of having a second school built in the vicinity where the new school is located.

Mr Agent Thorburn forwards under date 17th instant a resolution from the Chief and Counsellors of the West Bay Band for permission to build a frame schoolhouse the cost of which is to be borne by the capital funds of the Band. Specification for the erection of the Protestant School House at the Fort Bay Reserve.

Description

A two story frame building on a stone foundation. Size 50 ft. by 32 ft., with a porch 6 ft. by 10 ft. Height of the ceilings above the ground and first floors to be 9 ft. and 8 ft., 6 ins., respectively.

Foundation

Plain rubble masonry. The walls are to be 1 ft. 6 ins. thick; 4 ft. 6 ins. in the ground and 1 ft. 6 ins. above. The outside walls are to be pointed above the ground. Build two piers, 16 ins. square of brick or stone to receive two 8 ins. X 8 ins. columns as per drawing.

The walls, piers and chimney are to have continuous courses extending 6 ins. on either side and 6 ins. thick.

Lay 2 ins. planking on the top of the walls and piers and bed the same in mortar ready to receive the joints.

Chimney

Build from the foundation courses already mentioned, a one half brick thick chimney with three flues 8 ins. X 8 ins.

A cupboard in chimney in the school-room as shown on the drawing. The portion of the chimney in the first floor is to be plastered on the outside like the walls; the chimney in the school-room is to be built of selected bricks and left bare. Carry the chimney to a height of at least one foot above the ridge roll of the roof and carefully purge the flues throughout their length.

Provide and fit suitable coal boxes and doors, and make pipe holes and supply the thimbles as required where shown in the chimney and over the doors and in the floor as per drawing.
Ventilators

Put four iron ventilators in the outer walls of the school-room, two on either side of the room.

Beams and Columns

The ground and first floors are to be supported where shown by 8 in. x 12 in. pine beams, extending in one piece from end to end of the building. The beam over the school-room is to be supported where shown on the drawing by 8 in. x 8 in. pine columns resting directly on the 8 in. x 12 in. beam below. Chamfer the angles of the 8 in. x 8 in. joints.

Joints

The floor joists of the ground and first floors are to be 8 in. x 12 in. and 8 in. x 10 in., respectively set at 3 ft centres and to be continuous from wall to wall, i.e., 24 ft. long.

Double joists under the partitions and 6 ins. thick joists for trimmers for the stairs.

Lay one row of herring bone bridging down the centre of the longer span of the ground and first floor joists.

Ceiling joints to be 6 in. x 6 in., set at 18 inch centres and well nailed to the rafters.

Furring

For the second story; to be 1 1/4 dressed, tongued and grooved and blind nailed; for the ground floor to be the same nailing laid on a floor of one inch rough boarding. This one inch rough boarding to be put on diagonally and well nailed to the joists.

The studs of the walls and partitions are to be 2 in. x 4 in. at 16 inch centres. Double at all windows, doors, corners, &c.
Walls

Outside walls to be boarded on the outside with 1 in. rough boarding and covered with tar paper and clap boarding.

The inside of the walls and partitions and ceilings, except the underside of the wainscoting of the school-room, porch and kitchen which is to receive but one coat of plaster are to be lathed and plastered in two coats work and hard finished.

Wall plates, 2 in., X 4 in double.

Wainscoting:

Wainscot the walls of the school-room, porch and kitchen with double beaded wainscoting, 4 ft. high mounted with a cap. The wainscoting is to be well nailed to the studs and lathing.

The rafters are to be 8 in. X 1 in., at 16 inch centres. Cover the rafters with rough boarding tar paper and shingle with best mawn cedar shingles, hips, to the weather. The hips and ridge of the roof to be covered with weather boards and roll.

The eaves and cornices are to be plainly finished with 1 in. dressed boards.

Doors:

The porch and school-room doors are to be 4 ft. X 7 ft., four panelled and 1 3/4 thick. Both doors are to be provided with strong serviceable locks with two keys each.

Doors of the first floor to be 3 ft. 6 in. by 6 ft. 2 ins., four panelled and 1 1/4 thick and provided with suitable locks, handles, etc.

Windows:

To be 1. two sashes. The upper most fixed; the lower to raise. The two windows in the rear are to be similar to the two front ones. Glass with two lights over the entrance door of the porch.
Provide and fix all necessary fixtures.

Architectural
Carry simple architraves at least 5 ins. wide around the windows and doors and a 10 in. wide base board at the base of all walls.

Hooks and Shelves
Provide and place three dozen wire hooks in the living and bed-room closets and in the hall. Put a shelf 6 ft. above the floor in the closets of these rooms. The kitchen closet to be fitted up with shelves for a pantry.

Platform
Build a raised platform, 4 ft. 6 ins. wide and 2 ins. above the level of the school-room floor where shown on the drawing.

Wainscoting
Two spaces on the rear wall between the chimney and each side wall are to be painted on the plaster with prepared blackboard paint, to a height of 7 ft., 6 ins., above the top of the wainscoting.

Form a ledge on the top of the wainscoting to hold the brushes and chalk.

Stairs
Build stairs to the first floor where shown on the drawing in a neat substantial manner, width of stairs 3 ft., 6 ins., fifteen risers, 10 ins. treads.

The stairs will be inclosed below in matched and tongued panels, with a closet under.

Glazed handrail balusters and newel post in the hall above.

Floor
The foundation, flooring and walls are to be the same as the main building. Joists 2 ins. X 6 ins., at 16 ins. centres. Rafters 2 ins. X 4 ins., at 16 inch centres braced half way up with 1 in X 8 in bracers, these with the ends...
of the rafters will form the ceiling. Ceiling to be lathed and plastered, two coat work, hand finish.

Build strong and properly footed steps to the porch.

Painting: Prime and paint in two coat work with white lead and linseed oil paint of approved colors, the whole of the wood work both outside and inside usually painted.

A good, plain, substantial building complete in every respect is to erected of sound materials and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent or other officer who may be appointed by the Department of Indian Affairs for the purpose.

Your Indian Agent at Gore Bay informs me you expect me to put some additional work on the West Bay Schoolhouse, and I beg to explain as follows:— There were no plans or specifications of the shed, only what James H. Thorburn told me before witnesses, when I offered to erect the shed for the $65.00 additional to original contract, and I have now done more than agreed with Mr. Thorburn, and have put more money now in the shed than I am to get for it, and will show you by the following statement how the money was spent:

- 2100 ft dressed lumber at $20.00 per M delivered = $40.00
- 800 ft scantling and rough lumber at $18.00 = $14.40
- 3½ M. shingles at $2.25 per M. delivered = $7.88
- 2 doors and 8 frames cost = $7.50
- Nails, locks Butts, etc. about = $4.00
- Sills and work for foundations = $3.00

Besides the work of erecting, shingling, etc.

Hoping you will see by above I have fully completed my verbal contract, and that I would have been money ahead had I left the shed contract alone. Trusting to receive cheque in settlement in full without delay I remain,

Yours very truly,

Sgd Oliver Berry.

MEMORANDUM:

On Saturday the first of June I drove with Mr. Agent Baxter from Gore Bay to West Bay and visited the school in charge of Miss Laferrier, a lay sister who has had ten years experience in teaching. She had an enrolment of 45, 20 boys and 25 girls. The register is well kept and shows that the pupils are well advanced. The children that I met all understood English and answered questions well.

You will see from the accompanying snapshot that they have a comfortable school building with teachers' quarters, but a few repairs are needed. The foundation wants pointing; the roof should be attended to as it leaks in one or two places near the chimney; the grounds should be graded up a little higher around the building and drains should be dug to the gully in the rear, which would carry off the water which lies around the building after a heavy rain. The distance from the school to the gully is 94 feet with plenty of fall. Wire windows should be furnished as
the mosquitoes and black flies are troublesome. There is no artificial ventilation in the school-room, but a ventilator could be put into the chimney.

Miss Laferriere asked for a flag and I think one should be furnished her.

The teacher gives instruction in sewing and cooking and she should have some assistance in providing a light mid-day meal for the pupils as it would insure more regular attendance and afford an opportunity of giving practical lessons in cooking.

There is no caretaker and I would recommend that one be appointed.

The quarters over the school building proper are in good shape, but the kitchen in the rear might be improved and the pantry adjoining should be sheeted, and as it is only clapboards on the outside and is very cold in the winter.

Miss Laferriere is teaching gardening and has a very nice garden plot well fenced and well kept. It is 215 feet long by 20 broad, divided into 26 separate beds, well stocked with flowers and vegetables, all of which were well up and gave promise of a good yield. Miss Laferriere should be supplied with a watering pail.

There is space between the side windows in the school-room for blackboards and I would recommend that two hyloplates
hyloplate boards 9' x 3' be furnished as the two in use are small and well worn.

The school grounds are well fenced and neat in appearance.

A truant officer should be appointed.

Chief Peter Ace brought out a quantity of hardwood which was sawn at the mill for the purpose of flooring the school-room. I think it would be well to use this lumber for the purpose for which it was intended and they should be allowed to put up an implement shed at the back as they have a very good stock of garden tools which will only be destroyed if proper provision is not made for their care.

I was very much pleased with my visit to this reserve and I think that Miss Laferriere is deserving of all encouragement that the Department can give her. She has an assistant who helps her in the care of the household arrangements.

I would suggest that Mr. Baxter be asked to send in a detailed report as to what is absolutely necessary to be done to the school at once so that the work might be undertaken during the holidays.

I have the honor to reply to Department Letter number 151727/5 under date of July 8th 1912 and would say that I have visited West Bay school in company with Mr. Chief and Councilor and thereby make the following suggestion. First that the present kitchen and pantry which is 12 feet x 22 feet in size be torn down and a new kitchen & pantry 15 feet x 26 feet be built onto the school. The present kitchen is in my estimation too small for the work that Miss Superior is trying to do in regards to the cooking class that she has. The cost of material and labour would be about five hundred and fifty dollars as near as we could estimate.

As for the grading of the school grounds close to the school I would not recommend that but would recommend filling in around the school with gravel which would take about fifty loads at thirty-five cents a load. The water from the roof of the school on account of our Eau Claire has washed the sand away from the building and I think it would only be lost time and money grading up more sand to the building.

As to painting the wall and repainting around the chimney I think it would
takes about four bags cement at sixty cents a bag and about two days labour at a dollar and fifty cents a day.

I would recommend a tile drain from the cellar out to a distance of one hundred feet; the cost of which would be about fifteen dollars and fifty cents.

I would also recommend ten window screens at a cost of three dollars and eighty cents; also twenty-five feet of foul air pipe and tripod at a cost of five dollars.

As to the hard wood flooring gotten out by the Indians there is not enough to do the school-room and the present floor is not in very bad condition yet. I would recommend leaving the school floor as it is at present and use the lumber gotten out by the Indians for the new kitchen.

I would also recommend that the fence posts and outside doors be painted which would require about three gallons of paint.

As to the appointing of a caretaker and steward office the Chief has promised to let me know in a few days who would be a good man for the position and what salary he would accept.

Sir,

I beg to refer to official letter of April 4th last, in regard to the furnishing of a pipe for the chimney of the kitchen of the West Bay School and to ask you to let the Department know by return mail what action you have taken in this matter.

As you are aware the teacher of this school is taking the second year's course at the Ontario Agricultural College and the Department wishes to provide every facility for experimental work at this school upon the completion of this course.

The soil is not very suitable for gardening here and it will be necessary to provide a few loads of black mud to mix with it. The teacher states that this was promised her last spring, but nothing was done. The Department must insist on its being done without any further delay. She also states that she purchased some fertilizers so that she has not yet been paid for them. Please let me know these should be forwarded.

I have to ask you to be good enough to obtain an estimate of the cost of a suitable woodshed and let the Department have a description of the shed. This must be erected within the next couple of months.

The teacher also asked for shutters to protect

the windows when the school is not in operation and you should at the same time submit an estimate of the cost of these.

The grounds in front of the building require to be levelled and you should engage an Indian to do this during the holidays.

This school is very well kept and the teacher deserves every encouragement. But, I believe, someone is neglectful, for the teacher has not received anything since March for money laid out in gardening, prizes and care of school, etc. There is certainly little use in preparing teachers for gardening and agriculture unless they are assisted in preparing the grounds.
MEMORANDUM,

Mr. Pedley,

Some time ago your attention was directed to Mr. Agent Baxter's (Gore Bay) inattention to his duties. The quarterly returns for the West Bay and Sheshogwaning Schools have never been forwarded, although placed in his hands at the end of June by the respective teachers. We have had, therefore, to make payment of their salaries without the usual voucher.

At both these schools there are other urgent matters requiring attention and at both of them also there are outstanding accounts which have not been paid. The teachers of both of these schools out of their meagre salaries have made payments direct for certain supplies and services and have not been reimbursed because Mr. Baxter will not forward the necessary vouchers for the Department to make payment. In the meantime the teachers have been asked to obtain receipts for the payments they have made and forward them direct to the Department so that payment can be made to them.

At West Bay a woodshed is needed. They have no well.
well. Shutters are required for the windows, as the school was broken into both last summer and this summer. The grounds have to be levelled and prepared for gardening operations, as the teacher has taken two courses at the Ontario Agricultural College and wishes to give particular attention to this.

At Shoeshewaning the teacher paid for wood in the latter part of the winter and has not been reimbursed. Also an Indian named Wilson Samson did small jobs around the school for the teacher, for which she paid and has not been reimbursed. A well is much needed at this school and the grounds have to be fenced and, although the Agent was written to on July 22, last, drawing his attention for the second time to these matters, there has been no reply. The roof of the school building is leaking and the furnace is not working properly. These are matters that should be attended to before the wet and cold weather sets in. In the spring also the teacher of this school sent in a requisition for certain supplies articles of furniture which it is customary for the Department to supply, but this has never been forwarded to the Department.

It would hardly seem possible to allow matters to go along indefinitely in this way and if the Agent will not attend
attend to them somebody else should be given authority to have the work done.

A.F. [signature]

The last thing which has impressed me most was the rapid advance in the church. Having not been back yet from the mission where they operate, I was very much surprised when I heard about the splendid work being done there. I was disappointed not to find any for I was sure you had granted one.
